isis.stitle: DOUBLE DIAPHRAGM ANCHORLOK SPRING BRAKE - OPERATION

svcproc.title: OPERATION
svcproc.para: In normal operation (brakes released), the brakes are held released by the diaphragm return spring in the service brake chamber ( Figure 2).
Air reservoir pressure in the spring brake chamber working against the spring brake diaphragm holds the power spring compressed.
In normal braking (service brake applied), air pressure from the brake valve working against the service brake diaphragm applies the service brakes ( Figure 3).
Air reservoir pressure in the spring brake chamber holds the power spring compressed. Normal service brake operation is not affected by the spring brake.

For parking or making an emergency brake application, the air pressure is exhausted from the spring brake chamber. This permits the power spring to expand, moving the spring brake push rod and the service brake push rod to apply the brakes ( Figure 4).

figure.caption: Figure 4. Emergency or Parking Brake Applied

svcproc.para: Loss of air pressure in the system results in loss of air pressure in the spring brake chambers and the power spring applies the brakes ( Figure 4).

In the event it is necessary to move the vehicle after an emergency application and before air pressure is restored, the power spring can be compressed mechanically to release the brake. Refer to CAGING SPRING.

A release stud (spring caging tool) is furnished with the Double Diaphragm Anchorlok Assembly. The release stud engages in the compression spring pressure plate. The nut on the stud is tightened to compress (cage) the power spring and release the brake ( Figure 5). Refer to CAGING SPRING.

figure.caption: Figure 5. Tighten Nut on Release Stud
